messages: 2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d (18:40): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Could very well be
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:57): discovers a program that uses SGML for documentation, which uses the syntax like <em/this/
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:57): I didn't know anybody seriously used that feature
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:59): 2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d, it seems like it's a Greek bastardization of the Aramaic for "my God", "eli".
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:07): http://www.w3.org/2010/Talks/doclicense-20100323/#(7) license proliferation fail

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:19): "Survey results on question "should W3C publish HTML 5 under a license that allows forking?". Of those who responded, approximately 79% answered "no" and 14% answered "yes" (and the rest abstained)."
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:19): Does it matter?  It's all published by the WHATWG too.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:20): I wonder why they want to attempt to prohibit forking, when the W3C version is already a fork itself
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:21): It's only bad when people you don't like do it
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:21): It's only bad when people other than you do it.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:22): Fork is a loaded word, after all
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:22): It implies there still being an original
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:23): Does it?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:23): just saw this smilie: ‡?†_‡?†
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:23): <3 Unicode
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:23): ‚ô• Unicode, too
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:23): Otherwise it's just "resuming the work" or "picking up the project"
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:23): When there's a fork in a road, I'd expect that to be two equally divergent paths
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:24): "Fork" implies there's still an original, at the moment of forking.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:24): One or the other may subsequently die, of course.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:24): and in a utensil-style fork I wouldn't expect there to be a primary tine
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:24): Stick to spoons, ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:24): so it's odd that in software it has a different connotation
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:25): It's not that odd. They simply focused only on the splitting aspect
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:26): I could look up "fork" in the OED to see whether the name for the utensil or the meaning of bifurcation came first.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:26): bifurcation doesn't imply a original either, does it?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:27): It implies one thing becoming two.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:27): Not with either one necessarily different from the other.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:27): "Conclusion: For HTML 5, create a new license that addresses all of the use cases cited by the HTML Working Group except forking." - maybe the best way to address the uses cases would be to not address them, to avoid wasting effort given the WHATWG copy already addresses the use cases in a far simpler and less proliferatively way
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:28): Clearly we need a new word
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:29): Cloning doesn't work, because a fork isn't identical except at the very beginning
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:30): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: It suggests the "pronged instrument" version was used two hundred years before any other use
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:30): I guessed that from the ordering of the definitions in the AHD.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:30): I think that usually orders chronologically.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:30): "c1000 ?ÜLFRIC  Hom. (Th.) I. 430 {Edh}a  cwelleras..wi{edh}-ufan  mid heora forcum hine {edh}ydon."
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:31): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: Clones aren't identical except at the beginning, either
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:31): though they may follow somewhat similar paths of development
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:32): spawn

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:32): it'll be extremely interesting to see how they are going to disallow forking while permitting the inclusion in open-source code so that the code stays as open source
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:32): but e.g. Republic clone troopers didn't all end up as bounty hunters
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:32): "a soft, jelly-like substance containing the eggs of fish, or of animals such as frogs"
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:32): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, why does open-source code need to include a copy of HTML5?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:33): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: see the list of use cases
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:33): has given up on the W3C anyway, honestly
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:35): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: That's more like using a different compiler, the source code is still identical ;)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:35): Was http://www.w3.org/2010/Talks/0323-html-plh/ meant to have more than just a title page?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:35): I need to press arrow keys, apparently
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:35): was attempting to just disable stylesheets in order to get a readable version of it

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:41): Say I have a collection of 10 blog previews, each with a title and part of the first paragraph of the blog; would all of these pieces belong to a section or an article?
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:41): each piece in <article>

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:43): Okay, so now say I have a rotating banner of various slogans pointing to articles, similar to the previews, but now in <img /> form, would you still recommend several <article>s?  I feel like the entire group is either an article or a section.

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:44): I may be changing our rotating banner @ http://www.liferay.com/ in response to http://html5gallery.com/2010/03/liferay/ since I'm on the fence about whether or not I agree with their assertion.
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:45): see http://edward.oconnor.cx/2009/09/using-the-html5-sectioning-elements#archive-pages for more
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:46): I would still recommend several <article>s, yeah
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:46): <div class="fancy-banner-thingy"><article>...</article><article>...</article>...</div>
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:47): (<article>s with <a rel="bookmark" ...><img ...></a> inside)
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:47): Well, in that case, wouldn't they belong to a banner section?
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:48): Only use <section> if it a) has its own heading and b) should affect the document outline
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:48): I don't see a heading that refers to the collection of those blurbs
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:49): <section> doesn't just mean "<div> 2: <div> harder"
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:49): Well, in this case, since they are part of the larger page and not on a page of their own, they would have a heading.
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:50): yes, each <article> has an obvious heading. I'm talking about the parent element.
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:50): the parent element doesn't have its own heading, so far as I can see
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:51): Yes, I'm refering to the parent element which wraps all of the articles.  At Liferay.com, we do have a heading to label the banners.
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:51): I don't see one
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:51): View the page without styling.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:51): Our presentational style is to remove the heading.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:52): As a group of previews of articles or an archive of articles, I think a heading is fitting, especially when there are other areas on the site which are not.
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:52): in that case, yeah, I'd use <section><h1>banners</h1><article>...</article>...</section>
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:52): on the site = on the page
2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d (19:53): mmm, that sputnik site is interesting

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:54): fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98, I'm compelled to feel that way too, except that http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/sections.html#the-article-element does note <article> content is "intended to be independently distributable or reusable"
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:55): Whereas an archive may be such, previews of blog posts or a rotating banner may not.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:55): They are pieces of independantly distributable or reusable content.
2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d (19:55): In case people didn't know, http://sputnik.googlelabs.com/

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:00): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132: If it's just a snippet, I would *not* do <article>.  I don't want to see a snippet by itself, fullscreened or on its own page, so it's not appropriate for <article>.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:01): That's my rule-of-thumb.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (20:01): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, now what about a collection of snippits?
